captions.text:
Man, they weren’t kidding about this whole
Year of Luigi thing, were they? Luigi’s

Mansion, Mario and Luigi, Super Luigi U…oh,
just three of year’s best games, no big

deal. There were Luigi soundtracks, Luigi-themed
handhelds…there were Luigi sprites in Mario

3D World. So yeah, even big brother couldn’t
escape it. Luigi was a busy guy.

And somehow, he still found time to get a
medical license.
It’s Dr. Luigi for the Nintendo Wii U.

So with a puzzle series, like Dr. Mario, there’s
not usually much of a difference between the

games. Usually, the only thing that distinguishes
one sequel from another is that they’re

on a different system, or they have a couple
different modes. That’s not exactly the

case with this one. Now, Dr. Luigi still has
the same Dr. Mario, in its own mode. But it

also does some interesting new things that
actually change the formula.

But let’s start at the beginning. If you’ve
never played a Dr. Mario game…it’s real

simple. It’s a puzzle game in which you
have to clear the viruses inside a bottle.

You do that by dropping pills on top of them.
The catch is that they keep coming automatically.

You just have to move them around as they
fall. Get four colors in a row, including
viruses, and they go away.

Get the bottle too full of pills…and it’s
game over. Disease wins. And Mushroom Kingdom

diseases…I mean, just look at Bowser’s
kids. You don’t want any part of these diseases.

Anyway, that’s the classic Dr. Mario, and
if you’re not up for a change, you can play

it in Dr. Luigi. The Retro Remedy mode is
just the original Dr. Mario. But the two other

modes…that’s where Dr. Luigi gets interesting.
And like Retro Remedy, one is a mode you’ve

seen before. That’s the Virus Buster mode,
which is from Dr. Mario Online Rx, for the
Wii.
That’s where the GamePad comes in.

So in terms of the rules, it’s largely the
same as the Wii game. It’s Dr. Mario, but…with

more control over the pills. You could drag
them around the bottle by pointing with the

remote, which was awesome. It was like you
could touch them. Only with the GamePad, you

can. It’s just a perfect fit for the this
controller. Virus Buster is…amazing, with
a stylus.

It’s way faster and more precise than pointer
controls, but it’s more than that. It just

feels awesome, playing it like this. It’s
so smooth…just a standout moment for the
GamePad.

Now, the biggest change…is definitely the
third mode. It’s called Operation L, and

that’s the Luigi part of Dr. Luigi. And
this is where things get weird, because it

kind of changes the way you play Dr. Mario.
See, in previous games, the pills were always

the same shape. So the strategy was always
the same. Not the case this time.

In Operation L, Luigi actually throws pills
in these L-shaped packets. And not only are

they a completely different shape, but they
also have more segments. So moves that would’ve

been good moves in any Dr. Mario game before…could
be disastrous in Operation L.

This is easily the biggest tweak to the Dr.
Mario formula to date. It’s really the first

variation to change the game enough that…it
actually feels different. And there’s an

element of risk in here, too. See, the pill
packets are so large, they can actually knock

out a virus by themselves. Just one packet.
But it’s that extra pill segment, that bend

in the L…that’s what you have to worry
about. Clearing one virus could mean covering
another with the wrong color.

And if you make a mistake, that leaves a lot
more pills.
And that bottle fills up real fast.

So you’re getting classic Dr. Mario, a great
new Operation L version…and that incredible

touch-based Virus Buster mode, which is actually
my favorite part of the game. And there’s

also online multiplayer for the classic and
Operation L modes, which is awesome. But that

said…there are some drawbacks. For starters,
multiplayer is two-player only. No third or
fourth player.
Which sucks.

And the Mii support that made the Wii version
so charming has been scrapped, which also

sucks. Removing Miis is never a good thing.
And as much as I love the idea of changing

the look of the viruses…they’re not changed
in the bottle. Which is 
a weird inconsistency.

Every Nintendo system usually gets a Dr. Mario,
and they’re usually great games. The only

question is how do they compare against the
others? Dr. Luigi does a lot of awesome things,

things that make it better than any prior
version. Not the least of which is the music,

which includes unbelievable new versions of
the Dr. Mario classics.

The lack of three and four player support
is a huge drawback, but…otherwise, the game

is in perfect health. Dr. Luigi is one the
best Dr. Mario games to date, and easily the
most unique.

Even if Luigi is…overmedicating a bit. Alright,
don’t tell Mario.

title: CGR Undertow - DR. LUIGI review for Nintendo Wii U
